detaileddescription.para: Edge detected, debouncing
Press verified, not detecting longpress
Press verified, waiting for longpress timeout.
Longpress verified, waiting for neg-edge
Neg-edge received, debouncing
Neg-edge received after long-press, debouncing.
Button release verified.
EDGE detected doublepress
EDGE detected doublepress
DOUBLE PRESS verified, waiting for neg edge
DOUBLE PRESS verified, waiting for neg edge k

briefdescription.para: Button State.

detaileddescription.para: This enumeration describes whether the button is pressed or released etc. This is for internal state machine handling.
Button pressed down, may or may not subsequently have been released
Button held down for more than tLongpress (ms)
Button released after press or longpress
Button was pressed and released, but was not a long press
Button was pressed and released, and held for longer than longPressDuration (ms)
Button was pressed when double click detection was active

briefdescription.para: Button event flags.

detaileddescription.para: The event flags can be used by the user to subscribe to specific kinds of button actions and by the driver to signal which event caused a callback.
Button is PULLED DOWN.
Button is PULLED UP.
Button pull not set

briefdescription.para: Button Pull settings.

detaileddescription.para: This enumeration defines whether the GPIO connected to the button is PULL UP or PULL DOWN

briefdescription.para: Button configuration.

detaileddescription.para: Each Button_Config represents a single physical button. It contains pointers to the button's Button_HWAttrs and Button_Object. The user must statically allocate all of these structures.

briefdescription.para: A handle that is returned from a Button_open() call.

detaileddescription.para: User will use this handle to interact with a given button instance.

briefdescription.para: Button State.

detaileddescription.para: This enumeration describes whether the button is pressed or released etc. This is for internal state machine handling.

briefdescription.para: Button event flags.

detaileddescription.para: The event flags can be used by the user to subscribe to specific kinds of button actions and by the driver to signal which event caused a callback.

briefdescription.para: Event subscription and notification mask type.

memberdef.definition: typedef void(* Button_Callback) (Button_Handle buttonHandle, Button_EventMask buttonEvents)
memberdef.name: Button_Callback

briefdescription.para: A handler to receive button callbacks.
Button Pull settings.

detaileddescription.para: This enumeration defines whether the GPIO connected to the button is PULL UP or PULL DOWN

briefdescription.para: Hardware specific settings for a button.

detaileddescription.para: This structure should be defined and provided by the application. The index provided should correspond to a gpio pin in a GPIO_PinConfig array. This gpio pin should be the pin connected to the button and must be configured as GPIO_CFG_INPUT and GPIO_CFG_IN_INT_FALLING.

briefdescription.para: Button State Variables.

detaileddescription.para: Each button instance needs set of variables to monitor its state. We group these variables under the structure Button_State.

briefdescription.para: Internal to Button module. Members should not be accessed by the application.
Button Parameters.

detaileddescription.para: Button parameters are used with the Button_open() call. Default values for these parameters are set using Button_Params_init().

briefdescription.para: Function to close a Button specified by the Button_Handle.

simplesect.para: Button_open() had to be called first.

parameterdescription.para: A Button_Handle returned from Button_open() call

simplesect.para: True on success or false upon failure.

briefdescription.para: Function to initialize Button driver.
Function to open a given Button.

detaileddescription.para: Function to open a button instance corresponding to a Button_Config in the Button_config array. The GPIO configurations must exist prior to calling this function. The Button_Params may be used to specify runtime parameters.

simplesect.para: Button_init() has to be called first

parameterdescription.para: Logical button number indexed into the Button_config table
A Button_Callback that is called when a desired event occurs.
A pointer to Button_Params structure. If NULL, it will use default values.

simplesect.para: A Button_Handle on success, or a NULL on failure.

briefdescription.para: Function to initialize a Button_Params struct to its defaults.

parameterdescription.para: A pointer to a Button_Params structure that will be initialized.

briefdescription.para: Function to return the lastPressedDuration (valid only for short press, long press)

detaileddescription.para:
The API returns last pressed duration and it is valid only for shortpress, longpress. If this API is called after receiving an event click or long click then the API returns the press duration which is time delta between the press and release of the button.
This API call is only valid after a click or long click and not after a double click.
handle
Pointer to the Button_Handle of the desired button.
time duration in milliseconds.

briefdescription.para: Function to set callback function for the button instance.
This is the GPIO interrupt callback function which is called on a button press or release. This is internally used by button module.

detaileddescription.para: This function is internally used by button module for receiving the GPIO interrupt callbacks. This is exposed to the application for wake up cases. In some of the MCUs, when in LPDS(Low power deep sleep) the GPIO interrupt is consumed for wake up, and in order to make the button module work the the application has to call this API with the index of the GPIO pin which actually was the reason for the wake up.

parameterdescription.para: Index of the GPIO for which the button press has to be detected. This is an index in GPIO_PinConfig array.

briefdescription.para: Button driver.

detaileddescription.para: The Button driver simplifies interfacing push buttons. For example, push buttons on LaunchPads, BoosterPacks, or custom boards may easily be managed via the Button API. A given button instance may subscribe to one or several Button_Events. When a subscribed event occurs, the user will receive a callback with the handle of the button and the event(s) that occured.

Buttons use the GPIO.h interface for interfacing with hardware, so a GPIO_PinConfig array must exist and contain a config for the button pin. The user must statically allocate a Button_Config array called Button_config. Each physical button should map to an index in Button_config.

Each structure must be defined by the application. The following example is for a MSP432 in which two buttons are setup. The following declarations are placed in "ti_drivers_config.h" and "ti_drivers_config.c" respectively. How the GPIO configs are defined are detailed in the next example.
"ti_drivers_config.h" #defineCONFIG_BUTTON_00//Buttonnumber1 #defineCONFIG_BUTTON_11//Buttonnumber2

The following example is for a MSP432. We are showing interfacing of two push buttons. Each need a GPIO pin. The following definitions are in "ti_drivers_config.h" and "ti_drivers_config.c" respectively. This example uses GPIO pins 1.1 and 1.4. The other GPIO configuration structures must exist, see GPIO.h.
"ti_drivers_config.h" #defineCONFIG_S10 #defineCONFIG_S21
